title: Geometric Transformations: Rotation
contentHtml: In this example, we'll explore how to rotate a vector in 3D space.
problemHtml: Find the rotated vector v' when rotating v by an angle θ around the axis z.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the rotation matrix", "mathHtml": "\[R = \begin{bmatrix} \cosθ &- \sinθ & 0 \\ \sinθ & \cosθ & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We use the standard rotation matrix for rotating around the z-axis."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Write the vector in terms of its components", "mathHtml": "\[v = \begin{bmatrix} v_x \\ v_y \\ v_z \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "This helps us perform the rotation more easily." }, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Apply the rotation matrix to the vector", "mathHtml": "\[v' = Rv\]", "explanation": "We multiply the vector by the rotation matrix to get the rotated vector."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Simplify the result", "mathHtml": "\[v' = \begin{bmatrix} v_x \cosθ - v_y \sinθ \\ v_x \sinθ + v_y \cosθ \\ v_z \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "The resulting vector is the rotated version of the original." }, {"stepNumber": 5, "description": "Check your answer", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "Verify that the rotation matrix correctly transformed the vector." } ],
finalAnswer: The rotated vector v' is given by the formula above." },
intuition: Geometric transformations like rotations are essential in computer graphics, robotics, and many other fields. Understanding how to apply these transformations can help you create more realistic simulations or animations.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Geometric Transformations: Rotation
contentHtml: In this example, we'll explore how to apply a rotation transformation to a vector in 2D space.
problemHtml: Given the vector <math>\mathbf{v} = (3, 4)</math>, rotate it by an angle of <math>45^\circ</math> counterclockwise.",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the rotation matrix", "mathHtml": "\[ R(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos\theta & -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We use the standard formula for a 2D rotation matrix."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Substitute the angle", "mathHtml": "\[ R(45^\circ) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(45^\circ) & -\sin(45^\circ) \\ \sin(45^\circ) & \cos(45^\circ) \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We plug in the specific angle of rotation."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Apply the rotation matrix to the vector", "mathHtml": "\[ \mathbf{v}' = R(45^\circ) \mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(45^\circ) & -\sin(45^\circ) \\ \sin(45^\circ) & \cos(45^\circ) \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We multiply the vector by the rotation matrix to get the rotated vector."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Calculate the resulting vector", "mathHtml": "\[ \mathbf{v}' = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(45^\circ) & -\sin(45^\circ) \\ \sin(45^\circ) & \cos(45^\circ) \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2.1213 \\ 2.8284 \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We perform the matrix multiplication to get the final rotated vector."}, {"stepNumber": 5, "description": "Check our result", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "We can visualize the original and rotated vectors to verify the correctness of our calculation."} ],
intuition: Rotations are a fundamental concept in linear algebra, and understanding how to apply them can help you better grasp more complex transformations.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Geometric Transformations: Rotation
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll explore how to apply a rotation transformation to a vector in 2D space.
problemHtml: Find the image of the vector <math>\[ \mathbf{v} = (3, 4) \]</math> under the rotation transformation by an angle <math>\[ \theta = \frac{\pi}{6} \]</math>.",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the rotation matrix", "mathHtml": "\[ R(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos\theta & -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta \end{bmatrix} \]", "explanation": "The rotation matrix encodes the geometric transformation." }, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Compute the image vector", "mathHtml": "\[ \mathbf{v}' = R(\theta) \cdot \mathbf{v} \]", "explanation": "We apply the rotation to the original vector by multiplying it with the rotation matrix." }, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the image coordinates", "mathHtml": "\[ x' = 3\cos(\frac{\pi}{6}) + 4(-\sin(\frac{\pi}{6})) \]", "explanation": "We can now compute the new coordinates of the rotated vector." }, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Check the result", "mathHtml": "\[ x' = 2.5, y' = 3.33 \]" }, ],
finalAnswer: The image of <math>\[ \mathbf{v} = (3, 4) \]</math> under rotation by an angle <math>\[ \theta = \frac{\pi}{6} \]</math> is <math>\[ \mathbf{v}' = (2.5, 3.33) \]</math>" },
intuition: Geometric transformations like rotations are essential in computer vision and graphics. Understanding how to apply these transformations helps you work with images and 3D models.

problemHtml: Find the image of point P = (2, 3) under a counterclockwise rotation by \(45^\circ\) around the origin.",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the rotation matrix", "mathHtml": "\[R = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(45^\circ) & -\sin(45^\circ) \\ \sin(45^\circ) & \cos(45^\circ) \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We use the standard rotation matrix formula."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Compute the image of point P", "mathHtml": "\[P' = R P = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(45^\circ) & -\sin(45^\circ) \\ \sin(45^\circ) & \cos(45^\circ) \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We multiply the point by the rotation matrix."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Simplify the result", "mathHtml": "\[P' = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} (2-3) \\ \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} (2+3) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ \frac{5}{\sqrt{2}} \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We simplify the result by performing the matrix multiplication."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Verify the answer", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "We can verify our answer by visualizing the rotation or using other methods."} ],
